title: What you need to know about Foot-and-Mouth Disease.

tasks.task: Reporting Suspected Foot and Mouth Disease
subtasks: Recognize signs of FMD in livestock (cattle, pigs, sheep, goats)
Note symptoms specific to each species (e.g., fever, blisters, difficulty standing)
Identify high-risk conditions (recent contact with an infected farm, movement of animals)
Gather affected animals for veterinary assessment (e.g., isolated them)
Contact local veterinarian or authority immediately upon suspicion
Restrict movement of animals and people on the farm
Disinfect clothing, footwear, and equipment before entering the farm
Isolate contaminated materials (feed, bedding, water sources)
Clean and disinfect farm facilities (pens, buildings, vehicles)
Monitor imported animal products carefully (cooked or processed)
Be cautious of wind-borne transmission from nearby farms

tasks.task: Cooperate with Authorities in FMD Outbreak Response
subtasks: Comply with veterinary instructions for sample collection and testing
Adhere to containment protocols (quarantine unaffected animals)
Cooperate with notifications from local authorities re: contacts with infected farms
Stay informed about FMD prevalence in local and global markets
Report suspicious cases promptly to maintain disease-free status
Educate farm neighbors and community members about FMD control measures
